summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF whose interview became relevant to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) investigation into the JFK assassination. The HSCA interviewed Stevenson regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen, focusing on Stevenson's recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. His interview was reviewed by Julia Wetzel from the NSA, who recommended portions of the report be classified due to sensitive communications intelligence. The documents suggest Stevenson had information related to a facility able to collect the Lisbon-Tangier link, which was deemed sensitive enough to warrant classification.
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance lies in his potential knowledge of events or communications related to the JFK assassination, specifically concerning allegations made by David F. Christensen and his recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. The NSA's concern over the sensitivity of his interview suggests he possessed information deemed relevant to national security, possibly related to communications intelligence.
